skills.name: Place or identify the location of an integer less than 10 on a number line
Place or identify the location of an integer between 10 and 100 on a number line
Identify where negative integers between 0 and -10 lie on a number line

explanations.A: It seems like you may have gone to the left of -4, however as we move away from 0, the digit in the number increases so that would be -5!
explanations.C: It seems like you have gone one to the right of -2, however as we get closer to 0, the digit of the number decreases, so that would be -1!
explanations.D: This would be where a positive 3 would go, but the question is asking about negative 3.

explanations.A: This would be where a positive 2 would go, but the question is asking about negative 2.
explanations.B: It doesn't look like you've gone as many spaces as you need to! Have a think about how far away from 0 -2 would be.
explanations.C: -2 would be one greater than -3 which makes it one space closer to 0.
explanations.D: It seems like you've counted one space below -3, however with negative numbers, as we get away from 0 the digit increases so that would actually make -4.

explanations.A: It seems like you've just counted 4 spaces up from 30. Have a look really carefully at the scale on this number line!
explanations.B: It seems like you've just counted 4 spaces up from 30 - and that you included 30 (we never include the number we're starting from). Have a look really carefully at the scale on this number line!
explanations.C: The scale goes up in 2s, meaning we only need to go up from 30 by 2 jumps to increase by 4!
explanations.D: Check the scale really carefully - what is it going up in between the numbers?

explanations.A: It seems like you may have just chosen a number close to 27. Have a think about what the number line is going up in.
explanations.B: The number line is increasing by 2 with every jump. 31 is 4 more than 27, so we would need to go up two jumps which would put us on the triangle.
explanations.C: It looks like you could have counted down in 3s from 37, however we need to be really careful about what our number line is decreasing by.
explanations.D: It looks like you have counted up by 1 each jump from 27, however if you look at the numbers towards the top of the number line you can see that it doesn't increase by 1 with every jump. What does it increase by between each number?

explanations.A: It seems like you might think that each point on the number line increases by 2. Check carefully how many there are between -6 and -1, that will help you work out what it is going up in!
explanations.B: It looks like you might be counting as if the numbers are getting further away from 0, but would that be true if we're looking at a number between -6 and -1?
explanations.C: The scale is going up by 1 each time. If we count 3 spaces up the number line from -6, that would put us on -3.
explanations.D: Not quite - I think you have assumed that 0 is in the middle of the number line, however that isn't the case! See if you can figure out what the scale is going up by.

explanations.A: The number line increases by 1 with every jump. As we get closer towards 0 with negative numbers, the digits get smaller, so 2 greater than -5 would be -3.
explanations.B: It looks like you might be counting as if the numbers are getting further away from 0, but would that be true if we're looking at a number between -5 and 3?
explanations.C: Not quite, it looks like you've gone somewhere in the middle of -5 and 3 without thinking about exactly which number we are on. Think carefully here about what number is 2 closer to 0 than -5.
explanations.D: Close but I think you might be missing a negative symbol!

explanations.A: It seems like you may have just chosen the first shape at the top. See if you can figure out what the numbers are going down by each time.
explanations.B: The numbers are decreasing by 3 every time. 3 less than 7 would be 4, and then 3 less than that would be 1, so that is the star.
explanations.C: It seems like you might have just gone for what looks like it's in the middle of 7 and -8, however we need to think really carefully about what our number line is going down by each time and use that to work out where 1 would go!
explanations.D: It seems like you may have just chosen the first shape at the bottom. See if you can figure out what the numbers are going down by each time.

explanations.A: That would be correct for positive 4, however this question is asking about negative 4.
explanations.B: I think you may have miscounted here. Can you figure out what the number line is changing by with every jump?
explanations.C: It seems like you've counted up in 1s from the bottom, however if we look at the numbers towards the top of the number line, we can see that they don't increase by 1 every time.
explanations.D: The number line changes by 2 on every jump. -4 would be 2 up from -6 which would be one jump, so that would put us on the circle.

explanations.A: Not quite - it looks like you've found where -4 goes rather than 4.
explanations.B: It seems like you've counted in 1s back from 6. Check again carefully- do the numbers change by 1 every time?
explanations.C: Each jump on the number line is worth 2. So, we only need to go back one jump from 6 to find where 4 is!
explanations.D: It seems like you've counted in 1s up from 0. Check again carefully- do the numbers change by 1 every time?

explanations.A: I think you might have counted to the left from -7, however as we move away from 0 the digits get bigger so that would actually be -9!
explanations.B: The number line is increasing by 2 every time. -5 is 2 bigger than -7, so that would be one jump up.
explanations.C: It seems like you might think that the numbers are increasing by 4 every time, however that isn't the case for this number line. Check again to see if you can work out what each jump goes up by.
explanations.D: Not quite - that would be where + 5 goes, not - 5!
